description.narrative:
Organisation Olof Palmes Internationella Center (OPIC) har till Sida ansökt om finansiering av 34 miljoner kronor för att utföra programmet för Serbien 2016-2021. Projektet är en förtsättning på tidigare stöd med fokus på ökat åtnjutande av mänskliga rättigheter och stärkta möljigheter att utöva demokratiskt inflytande. OPIC har en unik kompetens och lång praktisk erfarenhet av demokratiutveckling och fattigdomsbekämpning och det ger OPIC goda möjligheter att arbeta för målet för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete - att bidra till att skapa förutsättningar för fattiga människor att förbättra sina levnadsvillkor.
OPICs förslag ligger i linje med den svenska resultatstrategin för reformsarbete med Öseuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet för perioden 2014-2020 som anger stöd till stärkt demokrati, ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och mer utvecklad rättsstat. Projektet är mycket relevant för Serbiens EU integrationsagenda eftersom ett aktivt civilsamhälle kan spela en viktig roll i genomförandet och uppföljningen av nationella och EU-prioriteringar och strategier.

new OPIC Serbia 2016-2021: Over the past four years, Serbia did not make significant improvements when it comes to reform processes and European Integrations. The existing focus on transparency and accountability, citizen participation and the legitimacy of civil society organisations will therefore remain, further emphasizing the importance of activism, movement building and membership.

description.narrative: The Programme Reports, meetings and field visits provide information on the results that have been achieved. Some of the most important results that have been achieved relate to increased legitimicy of implementing partners and most are recognised by state institutions, local authorities, international organisations and citizens in general as important stakeholders with good capacities to be relevant actors in areas of their work. CSO Radnik is a founder of the web portal www.radnik.rs – a credible source of information on workers’ and labour rights violations that workers report to Radnik. Communicating directly with workers is a very important activity because it enables workers to directly participate. They trust the organisation and report problems at the workplace and this way contribute to an increased awareness of labour rights violations while also contributing to analysing labour inspection actions and inspection control results. Radnik’s website and their social media channels attracted surprisingly high levels of attention from mainstream media. The editor-in-chief was interviewed numerous times on TV N1 on the labour rights issues such as the postal workers’ strike, violations of labour rights in public enterprises and state institutions, seasonal jobs, cases of fatal injures of construction workers etc. Radnik.rs was also cited in other media, such as daily Blic, Vecernje novosti, Danas, portal BBC on Serbian, 021, Nova ekonomija, Noizz, weekly Nedeljnik, etc. Toplica Center for Democracy and Human Rights and their associates organised local monitoring teams who improved their level of knowledge and understanding about Serbia’s EU accession, and problems in Chapter 5: Public procurement both on policy level and in practice. The findings of the Toplica Center and other members of the Coalition were partly utilized by the EU in their reports related to Chapter 5 of the negotiations and in Serbia country reports. Center for Democracy Foundation is leading the working group (WG17) in the National Convention on the EU-process. This group gathers civil society organisations that monitor the progress of EU negotiations related to Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement) and 19 (Social Policy and Employment). There are currently 54 members of the working group and they are involved in the process of official consultations regarding the Negotiation Chapter 19 through formal procedures and meetings with government representatives. Advocacy campaigns achieved several policy changes which proved that programme partners can influence the political agenda. The continuous work of Becej Youth Association has positively influenced the behaviour of the municipal authorities. The key result in 2019 is the implementation of the participatory budgeting process in the Local action plan for curbing corruption. The municipality adopted a new Statute for a mandatory participatory process, which is highly unorthodox in Serbia and with this change, the municipality of Becej became one of the first local authorities in the country that has participatory budgeting process both in their statute and in practice. The Mayor and chief of finance of municipality of Becej participated in public debates on budget priorities organised by BYA and they discussed with citizens on the draft budget for 2020 and on improvements on the Municipal Statute in order to include the participatory budgeting process. A regional network meeting with all OPC Western Balkan programmes was organized in Belgrade in March. Immediately at the meeting but even more during mid-term dialogue meetings, the vast majority of partners expressed great level of satisfaction with the opportunity to meet their colleagues working on similar topics in different parts of the country and the region. Most of them are in continuous communication, already working together inside or outside of Palmecenter frame and are planning joint actions in the near future. In relation to networking, the area of socio–economic rights presents a good example of how organisations can and should work together. Direct cooperation and coordination not only of programme partners active in this field but also their joint work with other trade unions, CSO’s, media and even some of the employers’ organisations, managed to contribute to improved visibility of the topics they are dealing with. The pressure they are putting on decision makers jointly creates an impact which is much higher than the simple sum of the efforts of individual parts of the network. However, civil society in general is far from always being recognised neither by the authorities nor by the citizens. Therefore, the programme continues to support the efforts of civil society to change that.
